title: Career Shift: Hannah Spencer's Journey from Plumbing to Parliament for the Green Party
summary: Hannah Spencer, a 34-year-old former plumber, has made history by winning a Westminster by-election for the Green Party in Gorton and Denton, Greater Manchester, becoming their first ever by-election winner. After leaving education at 16, she worked as a plumber and recently pursued plastering through a full-time course while campaigning. Spencer has political experience as the Green Party leader on Trafford Council and as a mayoral candidate for Greater Manchester in 2024. In her victory speech, she apologized to plumbing customers and emphasized her goal to advocate for blue-collar workers in Parliament. The Green Party now has five MPs with her addition. Media scrutiny arose during the campaign over a 2021 Mumsnet post where Spencer criticized takeaways in Levenshulme for allegedly crowding out independent businesses, but the party defended her comments as showing affection for the area. Spencer is noted for her straight-talking style and lifelong connection to Greater Manchester, having been born in Bolton.

background_read: In UK politics, by-elections occur when a parliamentary seat becomes vacant due to resignation, death, or other reasons, allowing parties to gain or lose representation. The Green Party, founded on environmental and social justice principles, has been growing its presence with MPs elected in general elections and now through a by-election win. Hannah Spencer's background as a plumber and councilor highlights a trend of diversifying political representation to include individuals from non-traditional careers. Media scrutiny often plays a role in campaigns, as past statements can be revisited to assess a candidate's views. Understanding local government roles, like council leadership, helps explain how politicians gain experience before entering national Parliament.
